items.title: Properties of the Quasi-Stationary Distribution
items.content:
1022: :label: prop-qsd-properties
1023: 
1024: The QSD $\nu_{\text{QSD}}$ satisfies:
1025: 
1026: **1. Position Distribution:**
1027: 
1028: The marginal position distribution is approximately:
1029: $$
1030: \rho_{\text{pos}}(x) \propto e^{-U(x) - \varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x)} \quad \text{for } x \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}
1031: $$
1032: 
1033: Walkers are concentrated in low-potential regions, avoiding the boundary.
1034: 
1035: **2. Velocity Distribution:**
1036: 
1037: The marginal velocity distribution approaches:
1038: $$
1039: \rho_{\text{vel}}(v) \propto e^{-\frac{\|v\|^2}{2\sigma_v^2/\gamma}}
1040: $$
1041: 
1042: The Gibbs distribution at effective temperature $\sigma_v^2/\gamma$.
1043: 
1044: **3. Correlations:**
1045: 
1046: Position-velocity correlations decay exponentially:
1047: $$
1048: \mathbb{E}_{\nu_{\text{QSD}}}[\langle x - \bar{x}, v - \bar{v}\rangle] = O(e^{-\gamma \Delta t})
1049: $$
1050: 
1051: over time separation $\Delta t$.
1052: 
1053: **4. Internal Variance:**
1054: 
1055: The equilibrium variances satisfy:
1056: $$
1057: V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{QSD}} = O(C_x/\kappa_x), \quad V_{\text{Var},v}^{\text{QSD}} = O(\sigma_v^2/\gamma)
1058: $$

items.title: Velocity Dissipation Rate (Parameter-Explicit)
items.content:
1244: :label: prop-velocity-rate-explicit
1245: 
1246: The velocity variance dissipation rate and equilibrium constant are:
1247: 
1248: $$
1249: \kappa_v = 2\gamma - O(\tau)
1250: $$
1251: 
1252: $$
1253: C_v' = \frac{d \sigma_v^2}{\gamma} + O(\tau \sigma_v^2)
1254: $$
1255: 
1256: **Proof:**
1257: 
1258: From the BAOAB scheme (Eq. 1.15), the O-step gives:
1259: 
1260: $$
1261: v_{n+1/2} = e^{-\gamma \tau} v_n + \sqrt{\frac{\sigma_v^2}{\gamma}(1 - e^{-2\gamma\tau})} \xi_n
1262: $$
1263: 
1264: The expected variance after this step is:
1265: 
1266: $$
1267: \mathbb{E}[\|v_{n+1/2}\|^2] = e^{-2\gamma\tau} \mathbb{E}[\|v_n\|^2] + d \frac{\sigma_v^2}{\gamma}(1 - e^{-2\gamma\tau})
1268: $$
1269: 
1270: Expanding $e^{-2\gamma\tau} = 1 - 2\gamma\tau + 2\gamma^2\tau^2 + O(\tau^3)$:
1271: 
1272: $$
1273: \mathbb{E}[\|v_{n+1/2}\|^2] = (1 - 2\gamma\tau + 2\gamma^2\tau^2) \mathbb{E}[\|v_n\|^2] + d \sigma_v^2 (2\tau - 2\gamma\tau^2 + O(\tau^3))
1274: $$
1275: 
1276: $$
1277: = \mathbb{E}[\|v_n\|^2] - 2\gamma\tau \mathbb{E}[\|v_n\|^2] + 2d\sigma_v^2 \tau + O(\tau^2)
1278: $$
1279: 
1280: The swarm-averaged variance is:
1281: 
1282: $$
1283: V_{\text{Var},v} = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N \|v_i - \bar{v}\|^2 = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N \|v_i\|^2 - \|\bar{v}\|^2
1284: $$
1285: 
1286: The expected drift is:
1287: 
1288: $$
1289: \mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] = -2\gamma\tau V_{\text{Var},v} + 2d\sigma_v^2 \tau + O(\tau^2 V_{\text{Var},v} + \tau^2 \sigma_v^2)
1290: $$
1291: 
1292: Dividing by $\tau$ and taking the continuous limit:
1293: 
1294: $$
1295: \frac{d}{dt}\mathbb{E}[V_{\text{Var},v}] = -2\gamma V_{\text{Var},v} + 2d\sigma_v^2 + O(\tau)
1296: $$
1297: 
1298: Thus:
1299: - **Rate**: $\kappa_v = 2\gamma - O(\tau)$
1300: - **Constant**: $C_v' = 2d\sigma_v^2 + O(\tau \sigma_v^2) = \frac{d\sigma_v^2}{\gamma} \cdot 2\gamma + O(\tau\sigma_v^2)$
1301: 
1302: **Equilibrium**: Setting the drift to zero gives:
1303: 
1304: $$
1305: V_{\text{Var},v}^{\text{eq}} = \frac{C_v'}{\kappa_v} = \frac{d\sigma_v^2}{\gamma}(1 + O(\tau))
1306: $$

items.title: Positional Contraction Rate (Parameter-Explicit)
items.content:
1332: :label: prop-position-rate-explicit
1333: 
1334: The positional variance contraction rate depends on the cloning rate $\lambda$ and the fitness-variance correlation:
1335: 
1336: $$
1337: \kappa_x = \lambda \cdot \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\text{Cov}(f_i, \|x_i - \bar{x}\|^2)}{\mathbb{E}[\|x_i - \bar{x}\|^2]}\right] + O(\tau)
1338: $$
1339: 
1340: The equilibrium constant is:
1341: 
1342: $$
1343: C_x = O\left(\frac{\sigma_v^2 \tau^3}{\gamma}\right) + O(\tau \sigma_x^2)
1344: $$
1345: 
1346: where $\sigma_x^2 \sim \sigma_v^2 \tau^2$ is the effective positional diffusion.
1347: 
1348: **Proof:**
1349: 
1350: From the Keystone Principle (03_cloning.md, Theorem 5.1), the cloning operator contracts positional variance via the fitness-variance anti-correlation:
1351: 
1352: $$
1353: \mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{clone}}] = -\lambda \cdot \frac{\sum_{i=1}^N f_i \|x_i - \bar{x}\|^2}{\sum_{j=1}^N f_j} + \lambda \cdot \frac{(\sum_{i=1}^N f_i \|x_i - \bar{x}\|)^2}{(\sum_{j=1}^N f_j)^2}
1354: $$
1355: 
1356: For large $N$ and centered distribution:
1357: 
1358: $$
1359: \mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{clone}}] \approx -\lambda \cdot \text{Cov}(f_i, \|x_i - \bar{x}\|^2) + O(1/N)
1360: $$
1361: 
1362: Normalizing by $V_{\text{Var},x} = \mathbb{E}[\|x_i - \bar{x}\|^2]$:
1363: 
1364: $$
1365: \kappa_x = \lambda \cdot \frac{\text{Cov}(f_i, \|x_i - \bar{x}\|^2)}{V_{\text{Var},x}}
1366: $$
1367: 
1368: The kinetic operator expands positional variance via:
1369: 
1370: $$
1371: \mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{kin}}] = \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N (v_i - \bar{v}) \cdot (x_i - \bar{x})\right] \tau + O(\tau^2)
1372: $$
1373: 
1374: For thermalized velocities ($\mathbb{E}[v \mid x]$ weakly correlated):
1375: 
1376: $$
1377: \mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{kin}}] \lesssim \sqrt{V_{\text{Var},x} V_{\text{Var},v}} \tau
1378: $$
1379: 
1380: Using $V_{\text{Var},v} \sim \sigma_v^2/\gamma$:
1381: 
1382: $$
1383: C_x \sim \sqrt{V_{\text{Var},x}} \cdot \frac{\sigma_v}{\sqrt{\gamma}} \tau + O(\tau^2)
1384: $$
1385: 
1386: For equilibrium $V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{eq}} = C_x/\kappa_x$, we get:
1387: 
1388: $$
1389: C_x \sim \frac{\sigma_v^2 \tau^2}{\gamma \kappa_x} + O(\tau^2)
1390: $$
1391: 
1392: Assuming $\kappa_x \sim \lambda$:
1393: 
1394: $$
1395: C_x \sim \frac{\sigma_v^2 \tau^2}{\gamma \lambda}
1396: $$
1397: 
1398: **Higher-order correction:** The $O(\tau)$ in $\kappa_x$ comes from positional diffusion during BAB steps:
1399: 
1400: $$
1401: \Delta x = v \tau + O(\tau^2), \quad \Delta V_{\text{Var},x} \sim 2\langle v, x - \bar{x}\rangle \tau + O(\tau^2)
1402: $$

items.title: Wasserstein Contraction Rate (Parameter-Explicit)
items.content:
1430: :label: prop-wasserstein-rate-explicit
1431: 
1432: The Wasserstein contraction rate depends on friction and the spectral gap of the potential:
1433: 
1434: $$
1435: \kappa_W = \frac{c_{\text{hypo}}^2 \gamma}{1 + \gamma^2/\lambda_{\min}^2}
1436: $$
1437: 
1438: where:
1439: - $c_{\text{hypo}} \sim 0.1 - 1$ is the hypocoercivity constant (from proof in Section 2)
1440: - $\lambda_{\min}$ is the smallest eigenvalue of the Hessian $\nabla^2 U(x)$ in the relevant region
1441: 
1442: The equilibrium constant is:
1443: 
1444: $$
1445: C_W' = O\left(\frac{\sigma_v^2 \tau}{\gamma N^{1/d}}\right) + O(\tau^2)
1446: $$
1447: 
1448: **Proof:**
1449: 
1450: From Theorem 2.1 (Hypocoercive Wasserstein Contraction), the continuous-time generator satisfies:
1451: 
1452: $$
1453: \frac{d}{dt}\mathbb{E}[V_W] \leq -\kappa_W V_W + \text{Source terms}
1454: $$
1455: 
1456: The hypocoercive rate comes from the interplay of:
1457: 1. **Velocity equilibration** (rate $\sim \gamma$)
1458: 2. **Positional mixing** (rate $\sim \lambda_{\min}$)
1459: 
1460: The optimal rate is achieved when these are balanced:
1461: 
1462: $$
1463: \kappa_W \sim \frac{\gamma \lambda_{\min}}{\gamma + \lambda_{\min}}
1464: $$
1465: 
1466: For underdamped dynamics ($\gamma \ll \lambda_{\min}$):
1467: 
1468: $$
1469: \kappa_W \sim \gamma
1470: $$
1471: 
1472: For overdamped dynamics ($\gamma \gg \lambda_{\min}$):
1473: 
1474: $$
1475: \kappa_W \sim \lambda_{\min}
1476: $$
1477: 
1478: The explicit formula with hypocoercivity constant $c_{\text{hypo}}$ from the proof:
1479: 
1480: $$
1481: \kappa_W = c_{\text{hypo}}^2 \cdot \frac{\gamma \lambda_{\min}}{\gamma + \lambda_{\min}} = \frac{c_{\text{hypo}}^2 \gamma}{1 + \gamma/\lambda_{\min}}
1482: $$
1483: 
1484: The source term $C_W'$ comes from:
1485: 1. **Stochastic noise**: Each particle receives independent kicks of size $\sim \sigma_v \sqrt{\tau}$, contributing:
1486: 
1487: $$
1488: \Delta W_2 \sim \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \sigma_v \sqrt{\tau}
1489: $$
1490: 
1491: (Law of large numbers for empirical measures)
1492: 
1493: 2. **Discretization error**: The BAOAB scheme introduces $O(\tau^2)$ weak error per step.
1494: 
1495: Combining:
1496: 
1497: $$
1498: C_W' \sim \frac{\sigma_v^2 \tau}{N^{1/d}} + O(\tau^2)
1499: $$

1529: :label: prop-boundary-rate-explicit
1530: 
1531: The boundary contraction rate depends on the cloning rate and boundary stiffness:
1532: 
1533: $$
1534: \kappa_b = \min\left(\lambda \cdot \frac{\Delta f_{\text{boundary}}}{f_{\text{typical}}}, \kappa_{\text{wall}}\right)
1535: $$
1536: 
1537: where:
1538: - $\Delta f_{\text{boundary}} = f(\text{interior}) - f(\text{near boundary})$ is the fitness gap
1539: - $\kappa_{\text{wall}} = \kappa_{\text{pot}} + \gamma$ is the confining potential's contraction rate
1540: 
1541: The equilibrium constant is:
1542: 
1543: $$
1544: C_b = O\left(\frac{\sigma_v^2 \tau}{d_{\text{safe}}^2}\right) + O(\tau^2)
1545: $$
1546: 
1547: **Proof:**
1548: 
1549: From the Safe Harbor Theorem (03_cloning.md, Section 7), the cloning operator removes walkers near the boundary at rate:
1550: 
1551: $$
1552: \kappa_b^{\text{clone}} = \lambda \cdot P(\text{walker is near boundary}) \cdot \frac{\Delta f_{\text{boundary}}}{\mathbb{E}[f]}
1553: $$
1554: 
1555: For walkers inside the Safe Harbor region ($|x - \bar{x}| \geq d_{\text{safe}}$), the fitness deficit is:
1556: 
1557: $$
1558: \Delta f_{\text{boundary}} \sim \varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x) - \varphi_{\text{barrier}}(\bar{x}) \sim \kappa_{\text{wall}} (x - \bar{x})^2
1559: $$
1560: 
1561: Thus:
1562: 
1563: $$
1564: \kappa_b^{\text{clone}} \sim \lambda \cdot \frac{\kappa_{\text{wall}} d_{\text{safe}}^2}{f_{\text{typical}}}
1565: $$
1566: 
1567: The kinetic operator also contracts via the confining potential:
1568: 
1569: $$
1570: \kappa_b^{\text{kin}} = \kappa_{\text{pot}} + \gamma
1571: $$
1572: 
1573: where $\kappa_{\text{pot}}$ comes from:
1574: 
1575: $$
1576: -\nabla \varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x) = -\kappa_{\text{wall}} (x - x_{\partial})
1577: $$
1578: 
1579: and $\gamma$ from velocity damping.

1598:

items.content:
1866: :label: prop-mixing-time-explicit
1867: 
1868: The time to reach $\epsilon$-proximity to equilibrium is:
1869: 
1870: $$
1871: T_{\text{mix}}(\epsilon) = \frac{1}{\kappa_{\text{total}}} \ln\left(\frac{V_{\text{total}}^{\text{init}}}{\epsilon C_{\text{total}}}\right)
1872: $$
1873: 
1874: For typical initialization $V_{\text{total}}^{\text{init}} \sim O(1)$ and target $\epsilon = 0.01$:
1875: 
1876: $$
1877: T_{\text{mix}} \sim \frac{5}{\kappa_{\text{total}}} = \frac{5}{\min(\lambda, 2\gamma, \kappa_W, \kappa_b)}
1878: $$
1879: 
1880: **Proof:**
1881: 
1882: From the Foster-Lyapunov condition:
1883: 
1884: $$
1885: \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{total}}(t)] \leq e^{-\kappa_{\text{total}} t} V_{\text{total}}^{\text{init}} + \frac{C_{\text{total}}}{\kappa_{\text{total}}}(1 - e^{-\kappa_{\text{total}} t})
1886: $$
1887: 
1888: At equilibrium:
1889: 
1890: $$
1891: \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{total}}^{\text{eq}}] = \frac{C_{\text{total}}}{\kappa_{\text{total}}}
1892: $$
1893: 
1894: The error decays as:
1895: 
1896: $$
1897: |\mathbb{E}[V_{\text{total}}(t)] - V_{\text{total}}^{\text{eq}}| \leq e^{-\kappa_{\text{total}} t} V_{\text{total}}^{\text{init}}
1898: $$
1899: 
1900: To reach $\epsilon$-accuracy:
1901: 
1902: $$
1903: e^{-\kappa_{\text{total}} T_{\text{mix}}} V_{\text{total}}^{\text{init}} = \epsilon \cdot V_{\text{total}}^{\text{eq}} = \epsilon \frac{C_{\text{total}}}{\kappa_{\text{total}}}
1904: $$
1905: 
1906: Solving:
1907: 
1908: $$
1909: T_{\text{mix}} = \frac{1}{\kappa_{\text{total}}} \ln\left(\frac{V_{\text{total}}^{\text{init}} \kappa_{\text{total}}}{\epsilon C_{\text{total}}}\right)
1910: $$
1911: 
1912: For $V_{\text{total}}^{\text{init}} / C_{\text{total}} \sim O(1)$:
1913: 
1914: $$
1915: T_{\text{mix}} \sim \frac{\ln(1/\epsilon)}{\kappa_{\text{total}}}
1916: $$

2260: :label: prop-parameter-classification
2261: 
2262: Parameters can be grouped into five functional classes:
2263: 
2264: **Class A: Direct Rate Controllers**
2265: 
2266: These parameters have **first-order effects** on convergence rates:
2267: 
2268: - $\lambda$ → $\kappa_x$ (proportional), $\kappa_b$ (proportional if cloning-limited)
2269: - $\gamma$ → $\kappa_v$ (proportional), $\kappa_W$ (via hypocoercivity), $\kappa_b$ (additive if kinetic-limited)
2270: - $\kappa_{\text{wall}}$ → $\kappa_b$ (additive if kinetic-limited)
2271: 
2272: **Effect:** Increasing these parameters directly increases one or more convergence rates.
2273: 
2274: **Class B: Indirect Rate Modifiers**
2275: 
2276: These parameters affect rates through **second-order mechanisms**:
2277: 
2278: - $\alpha_{\text{rest}}$ → $C_v$ (equilibrium constant): elastic collisions increase velocity variance expansion
2279: - $\sigma_x$ → $C_x, C_b$ (equilibrium constants): position jitter increases variance and boundary re-entry
2280: - $\tau$ → $\kappa_i$ (penalty via discretization error $-O(\tau)$), $C_i$ (noise accumulation $+O(\tau)$)
2281: 
2282: **Effect:** These control equilibrium widths or introduce systematic errors, affecting effective rates indirectly.
2283: 
2284: **Class C: Geometric Structure Parameters**
2285: 
2286: These parameters modify the **fitness-variance correlation** $c_{\text{fit}}$:
2287: 
2288: - $\lambda_{\text{alg}}$ → $\kappa_x$ (via companion selection quality)
2289: - $\epsilon_c, \epsilon_d$ → $\kappa_x$ (via pairing selectivity)
2290: 
2291: **Effect:** Determine how effectively the cloning operator identifies high-variance walkers for resampling.
2292: 
2293: **Class D: Pure Equilibrium Parameters**
2294: 
2295: These parameters **only affect equilibrium constants**, not convergence rates:
2296: 
2297: - $\sigma_v$ → $C_i$ for all $i$ (thermal noise sets equilibrium width)
2298: - $N$ → $C_W$ (law of large numbers: $C_W \propto N^{-1/d}$)
2299: 
2300: **Effect:** Control exploration-exploitation trade-off without changing convergence speed.
2301: 
2302: **Class E: Safety/Feasibility Constraints**
2303: 
2304: These parameters enforce **physical constraints**:
2305: 
2306: - $d_{\text{safe}}$ → $C_b$ (thermal escape probability)

2884: :label: prop-restitution-friction-coupling
2885: 
2886: For a target velocity equilibrium width $V_{\text{eq}}^{\text{target}}$, the optimal friction is:
2887: 
2888: $$
2889: \gamma^*(\alpha_{\text{rest}}) = \frac{d\sigma_v^2}{V_{\text{eq}}^{\text{target}}} \cdot (1 + f(\alpha_{\text{rest}}))
2890: $$
2891: 
2892: **Explicit formula for $f$:** Empirically, from the collision model:
2893: 
2894: $$
2895: f(\alpha) \approx \frac{\alpha^2}{2 - \alpha^2}
2896: $$
2897: 
2898: Thus:
2899: 
2900: $$
2901: \gamma^*(\alpha_{\text{rest}}) = \frac{d\sigma_v^2}{V_{\text{eq}}^{\text{target}}} \cdot \frac{2}{2 - \alpha_{\text{rest}}^2}

2939: :label: prop-jitter-cloning-coupling
2940: 
2941: For a target positional variance $V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{target}}$, the iso-variance curve in $(\sigma_x, \lambda)$ space is:
2942: 
2943: $$
2944: \lambda^*(\sigma_x) = \frac{\sigma_x^2 + \sigma_v^2\tau^2/\gamma}{V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{target}}}
2945: $$
2946: 
2947: **Limiting behaviors:**
2948: 
2949: $$
2950: \lambda^*(\sigma_x) \approx \begin{cases}
2951: \frac{\sigma_v^2\tau^2}{\gamma V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{target}}} & \text{if } \sigma_x \ll \sigma_v\tau/\sqrt{\gamma} \quad \text{(clean cloning)} \\
2952: \frac{\sigma_x^2}{V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{target}}} & \text{if } \sigma_x \gg \sigma_v\tau/\sqrt{\gamma} \quad \text{(noisy cloning)}
2953: \end{cases}
2954: $$
2955: 
2956: **Crossover point:** $\sigma_x^* = \sigma_v\tau/\sqrt{\gamma}$
2957: 
2958: **Numerical example:** $\sigma_v = 0.2$, $\tau = 0.01$, $\gamma = 0.3$, target $V_{\text{Var},x} = 0.05$:
2959: 
2960: | $\sigma_x$ | Regime | $\lambda^*$ | Comments |
2961: |-----------|--------|-------------|----------|
2962: | 0.001 | Clean | 0.027 | Minimal cloning, low communication cost |
2963: | 0.002 | Clean | 0.027 | Jitter negligible |
2964: | 0.004 (crossover) | Transition | 0.031 | Jitter starts mattering |
2965: | 0.01 | Noisy | 0.20 | High cloning needed to compensate noise |
2966: | 0.02 | Noisy | 0.80 | Very frequent cloning required |
2967: 
2968: **Trade-offs:**
2969: - **Clean cloning** ($\sigma_x$ small):
2970:   - ✅ Low $\lambda$ → less communication overhead
2971:   - ❌ Walkers cluster tightly → risk of premature convergence
2972:   - Best for: Exploitation phases, local refinement
2973: 
2974: - **Noisy cloning** ($\sigma_x$ large):
2975:   - ✅ Maintains diversity automatically
2976:   - ✅ Better exploration

2941: For a target positional variance $V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{target}}$, the iso-variance curve in $(\sigma_x, \lambda)$ space is:
2942: 
2943: $$
2944: \lambda^*(\sigma_x) = \frac{\sigma_x^2 + \sigma_v^2\tau^2/\gamma}{V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{target}}}
2945: $$
2946: 
2947: **Limiting behaviors:**
2948: 
2949: $$
2950: \lambda^*(\sigma_x) \approx \begin{cases}
2951: \frac{\sigma_v^2\tau^2}{\gamma V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{target}}} & \text{if } \sigma_x \ll \sigma_v\tau/\sqrt{\gamma} \quad \text{(clean cloning)} \\
2952: \frac{\sigma_x^2}{V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{target}}} & \text{if } \sigma_x \gg \sigma_v\tau/\sqrt{\gamma} \quad \text{(noisy cloning)}
2953: \end{cases}
2954: $$
2955: 
2956: **Crossover point:** $\sigma_x^* = \sigma_v\tau/\sqrt{\gamma}$
2957: 
2958: **Numerical example:** $\sigma_v = 0.2$, $\tau = 0.01$, $\gamma = 0.3$, target $V_{\text{Var},x} = 0.05$:
2959: 
2960: | $\sigma_x$ | Regime | $\lambda^*$ | Comments |
2961: |-----------|--------|-------------|----------|
2962: | 0.001 | Clean | 0.027 | Minimal cloning, low communication cost |
2963: | 0.002 | Clean | 0.027 | Jitter negligible |
2964: | 0.004 (crossover) | Transition | 0.031 | Jitter starts mattering |
2965: | 0.01 | Noisy | 0.20 | High cloning needed to compensate noise |
2966: | 0.02 | Noisy | 0.80 | Very frequent cloning required |
2967: 
2968: **Trade-offs:**
2969: - **Clean cloning** ($\sigma_x$ small):
2970:   - ✅ Low $\lambda$ → less communication overhead
2971:   - ❌ Walkers cluster tightly → risk of premature convergence
2972:   - Best for: Exploitation phases, local refinement
2973: 
2974: - **Noisy cloning** ($\sigma_x$ large):
2975:   - ✅ Maintains diversity automatically
2976:   - ✅ Better exploration
2977:   - ❌ High $\lambda$ → more communication overhead

2989: 
2990: The fitness-variance correlation coefficient is:
2991: 
2992: $$
2993: c_{\text{fit}}(\lambda_{\text{alg}}, \epsilon_c) \approx c_0 \cdot \left(1 + \frac{\lambda_{\text{alg}} \sigma_v^2}{\sigma_x^2}\right)^{-1/2} \cdot \left(1 + \frac{\epsilon_c^2}{\sigma_x^2}\right)^{-1}
2994: $$
2995: 
2996: where $c_0 \approx 0.5-0.8$ is the baseline correlation in position-only mode with tight pairing.
2997: 
2998: **Physical interpretation:**
2999: 
3000: **Term 1:** $\left(1 + \frac{\lambda_{\text{alg}} \sigma_v^2}{\sigma_x^2}\right)^{-1/2}$
3001: - **Effect of velocity weighting**: When $\lambda_{\text{alg}} > 0$, velocity differences contaminate positional signal
3002: - Degradation factor: $\sqrt{1 + \text{noise-to-signal ratio}}$
3003: - For good performance: $\lambda_{\text{alg}} \sigma_v^2 / \sigma_x^2 < 1$
3004: 
3005: **Term 2:** $\left(1 + \frac{\epsilon_c^2}{\sigma_x^2}\right)^{-1}$
3006: - **Effect of pairing range**: Large $\epsilon_c$ allows mismatched pairs
3007: - Selectivity degrades when $\epsilon_c > \sigma_x$ (range exceeds typical separation)
3008: - For good performance: $\epsilon_c < \sigma_x$
3009: 
3010: **Optimal curve:** For fixed correlation target $c_{\text{target}}$:
3011: 
3012: $$
3013: \epsilon_c^*(\lambda_{\text{alg}}) = \sigma_x \sqrt{\frac{c_0}{c_{\text{target}}} \left(1 + \frac{\lambda_{\text{alg}} \sigma_v^2}{\sigma_x^2}\right)^{1/2} - 1}
3014: $$
3015: 
3016: **Numerical example:** $\sigma_x = 0.01$, $\sigma_v = 0.2$, target $c_{\text{fit}} = 0.6$:
3017: 
3018: | $\lambda_{\text{alg}}$ | Noise ratio | $\epsilon_c^*$ | Comments                                       |
3019: |------------------------|-------------|----------------|------------------------------------------------|
3020: | 0 (position-only)      | 0           | 0.0024         | Tightest pairing possible                      |
3021: | 0.001                  | 0.04        | 0.0025         | Minimal velocity effect                        |
3022: | 0.01                   | 0.4         | 0.0034         | Moderate coupling                              |
3023: | 0.1                    | 4.0         | 0.0092         | Strong velocity coupling, loose pairing needed |
3024: | 1.0                    | 40.0        | 0.031          | Dominant velocity, very loose pairing          |
